thread.title: Trees on Adelaide housing development saved for now
thread.title_full: Trees on Adelaide housing development saved for now

title: Trees on Adelaide housing development saved for now
text:
Trees at Glenside housing development facing the chop saved for now Posted February 24, 2017 13:02:54 Map: Glenside 5065 
More than 80 significant trees set for removal from an Adelaide housing development have been saved for now. 
Developer Cedar Woods had planned to remove the trees from the Glenside Hospital site even though plans for the 1,000-home development are not complete. 
The Greens' South Australian Upper House MP Mark Parnell personally took the issue to the Development Assessment Commission (DAC), asking it to halt any further consideration of the development. 
He said some of the 83 trees could be hundreds of years old and a decision on their fate should be made only when the developer finalised its plans for the site. 
The commission on Friday decided to defer further consideration of the plans. 
"This is a welcome reprieve for the Glenside trees, but they are still at risk," Mr Parnell said. 
"Clearly the DAC wasn't satisfied with the developer's rationale for needing to remove all the trees at this stage. 
"The DAC wants more information about levels of contamination and plans for site remediation before considering the matter further. That is a good call." 
The South Australian Government had said that the trees and some contaminated soil needed to be removed as part of remediation work on the site and that 400 new trees would be planted. 
But Mr Parnell said removing soil from the entire site was an "exaggerated response" to a contamination problem that could be handled in other ways. 
"The site is not a toxic wasteland and clearly the DAC wasn't convinced either," he said. 
The development is going ahead on 16.5 hectares of land surrounding the Glenside Hospital. 
It was sold in July 2016 to Cedar Woods for $25.8 million. 
At the time, then minister for Housing and Urban Development Stephen Mullighan said the sale would help pay for a new mental health facility on the site. 
Residents raised concerns the project would cause traffic congestion and damage the area's heritage character.
